description.en: Gaining practical skills to work with microbes, doing research, growing and identifying microbes.
description.et: Praktilise töö kogemuste saamine mikroobidega töötamiseks. Tutvutakse mikroobide erinevate uurimisviisidega, nende kultiveerimise ja identifitseerimisega.

objectives.en: The aim of the Practical Course of Microbiology and Virology is to provide basic knowledge in understanding microorganisms and in handling them safely. Various experiments have been chosen to help students learn to recognize fundamental similarities and differences among microorganisms. The approach is ecological, attempting to give the students the knowledge how to isolate, inspect, inoculate, incubate, identify and enumerate microorganisms.
objectives.et: Mikrobioloogia ja viroloogia praktikum peab andma üliõpilastele algteadmised mikroorganismidest ja õpetama ohutut töötamist nendega. Mitmesugused ekperimendid on valitud nii, et üliõpilased õpiksid tundma põhilisi sarnasusi ja erinevusi mikroorganismide vahel. Ökoloogiline lähenemine annab üliõpilastele teadmised mikroorganismide isoleerimisest, inspekteerimisest, inokuleerimisest, inkubeerimisest, identifitseerimisest ja arvukuste määramisest.

learning_outcomes.en: After the course students are expected to:
- know how to work safely with different microbes and bacteriophages
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab ohutult töötada erinevate mikroobidega ja bakteriofaagidega

learning_outcomes.en: - have acquired the skills to use basic microbiological methods in different applications
learning_outcomes.et: - on omandanud oskused kasutada põhilisi mikrobioloogilisi meetodeid erinevates rakendustes

notes.et: The group limit will be increased as needed, with a maximum group size of 22.

independent_work.et: In the end of the course the student should hand in (in written form) summary of the results obtained on the subject VIII Pure cultures of microbes and their identification.

description.et:
The exam is in a written form.
The final score consists of three parts:
1. 1st part of the written exam (without any materials, 30% of the score)
2. 2nd part of the written exam (course manual can be used, 50% of the score)
3. Short summary of subject VIII (20% of the score)
Additional credits could be earned by correctly answering short tests at sessions and preparing correctly one fixed mount of microbes.

grade_preconditions.et:
To pass the course the student must participate in every session and finalize the practical assignments given during the sessions. It is allowed to miss up to two lessons due to the illness (you must provide medical documentation). If you are sick for a longer period  you can't finish the course and you must start next year from the beginning.
In the end of the course the student should hand in (in written form) summary of the results obtained on the subject VIII Pure cultures of microbes and their identification.

grade_evaluation.et:
The exam is in a written form.
The final score consists of three parts:
1. 1st part of the written exam (without any materials, 30% of the score)
2. 2nd part of the written exam (course manual can be used, 50% of the score)
3. Short summary of subject VIII (20% of the score)
Additional credits could be earned by correctly answering short tests at sessions and preparing correctly one fixed mount of microbes.
Grades:
 > 91% - A ; 
90-81% - B 
80-71% - C
70-61% - D
60-51% - E 
<51% - F (unsatisfactory).

debt_elimination.et:
It is possible to take the missed sessions ONLY if the supervisor allows it. It is allowed to be absent from the course 2 times with a medical certificate. If there are more absences, the course must be taken again in the new academic year.
Repeat exam can be done in accordance with the UT Study Regulations.

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et: 1. Introduction and safety instructions to work at microbiology laboratory. Short introduction to bright-field microscopy. I subject: Preparation, dying and inspection of microbiological specimens. Preparation of microbiological specimens, inspection of living cells. The effect of different environmental conditions to bacterial cells. Movements of bacteria.

2. I subject: Preparation, dying and inspection of microbiological specimens. Preparation of fixed mounts and inspection by bright-light microscopy in oil immersion system. Differential and special staining. Determination of bacterial Gram-reactivity. Bacterial endospores and storage structures.

3. I subject: Preparation, dying and inspection of microbiological specimens. Positive and negative staining. Differently shaped bacteria, pleomorfism and morphology of stressed bacteria. Microorganisms in food and fermentations. Bacterial flagellum.

4. II subject: Microbiological media, preparation and sterilization. Introduction to sterilizing methods in microbiology including autoclaving. Different media and their preparation requirements and techniques. Several media used during the course are prepared as a groupwork.

5. III subject: Aseptic techniques for inoculation. Overview of different inoculation methods and preparing dilutions. Inoculation of microbes to broths and agar plates: streaking, spread-plate, pour-plate, broth inoculations.

6. IV subject: Effect of environmental conditions on microbial growth. The effects of carbon sources, temperature, pH, oxygen, UV-radiation on microbial growth. Decimal reduction time and cell viability. Calculations of microbial cell numbers.

7. V subject: Determining the cell numbers and masses of microbes and VI subject: Microbiological analysis of water. Overview of evaluation methods on bacterial cell number and mass. Microbiological analysis of water: spread-plate, drop-plate, filtering, most probable number. Determination of microbe concentration in the air by Koch's plate exposure method.

8. V subject: Determining the cell numbers and masses of microbes and VI subject: Microbiological analysis of water. Overview of coliform bacteria and their fermentation capacity. Determination of the numbers of Escherichia coli and coliforms in natural water. Bacterial count in the air. Determining the number of live cells directly by fluorescence microscopy.

9. V subject: Determining the cell numbers and masses of microbes and VI subject: Microbiological analysis of water. Numbers of different bacterial groups in natural water. Testing the beta-glucuronidase activity by fluorescent substrate and testing the presence of gusA gene by PCR.

10. VI subject: Microbiological analysis of water and VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification.Testing the beta-glucuronidase activity by fluorescent substrate and testing the presence of gusA gene by PCR. Summary of microbe counts in natural water. Streak-plate for obtaining a pure culture of bacterium.

11. VII subject: Studying the growth of microbial population and VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification. Overview of growth phases of bacteria. Generation time and the relations of cell numbers and biomass. Optical density of microbial culture. Colony morphology determination.

12. VII subject: Studying the growth of microbial population and VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification. Growth of E. coli in batch culture, growth curve. Tests to identify the strain.

13. VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification and IX subject: Antibiotic susceptibility of bacteria. Overview of antibiotics and their mechanisms of action. Susceptibility test of the type strains. Analysis of E. coli growth curve, generation time calculations. Tests to identify the strain.

14.  VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification and IX subject: Antibiotic susceptibility of bacteria. Summary of antibiotic susceptibility testing. Summary of the tests on the strain under study. 16S rRNA analysis to identify the strain.

15. VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification. Polyphasic identification of a microbe. Bergey manuals for bacterial identification. Summary of the tests on the strain under study. Determination of the bacterium on species level. Comparison of the properties with closest identified strain.

16. VIII subject: Pure cultures of microbes and their identification. Identify the strain and prepare summary in a written form. Word or pdf file should be uploaded in Moodle (or alternatively sent to the supervisor) before the exam.
